div.head: Napoleonic Monuments in Milan
div.p: When the Ruskins visited Milan in 1833, Ruskinʼs cousin, Mary Richardson, took note especially of Napoleonic monuments in the city. In Ruskinʼs extant writing about the city for the Account of a Tour on the Continent—the poem “Milan Cathedral”—his imagination is captured by the vertical thrust of the Gothic architecture complemented by the mountain heights beyond the city. In contrast, a planned but apparently unexecuted section for the “Account”, “The Corso of Milan”, presumably would have reflected the horizontal expanse of neoclassical and Napoleonic‐era monuments in the city (see Diary of Mary Richardson, 1833; Plan for the Continuation of the Account of a Tour on the Continent).

During the Enlightenment, under the administration of the Hapsburgs, urban planning in neoclassical style for Milan was overseen by the architect Giuseppe Piermarini (1734–1808). The Ruskins visited his most famous building, the Teatro alla Scala (1776–78), although they were unable to attend a performance, and they would have encountered other structures associated with Piermariniʼs neoclassical renovations throughout the city. For example, the corso that Ruskin planned to write about and that Mary mentions in her diary was most likely the Corso di Porta Orientale (also known as the Porta Venezia), which underwent modernization between 1827 and the year of the Ruskinsʼ visit, 1833. Designed by Rodolfo Vantini (1792–1856), its gateway is marked by a pair of cubical structures that, like the Brandeburg Gate in Berlin, evoke the Propylaea of the Acropolis in Athens. In the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, such imposing neoclassical gates were meant to herald the entrance to the city conceived as “work of art” (Etlin, Symbolic Space, 2–4; and see Olsen, The City as a Work of Art).

By the 1830s, however, the Enlightenment Hapsburg project in Milan had been overlain by Napoleonʼs ambitions for the city, which appropriated the neoclassical design to promote republican and imperial ideals. This symbolism was often expressed using a columnar, Doric vocabulary associated with Paestum. The Ruskins appear to have sought out these Napoleonic monuments, including a vast “amphitheatre”, referring apparently to the Foro Bonaparte (1801-6), planned by Giovanni Antonio Antolini (1756-1841) as a spectacular entrance to the city from the Strada del Sempione, connecting to the Simplon Pass, which Napoleonʼs engineers had modernized as an accessible carriage road. The Foro Bonaparte was completed in altered form by Luigi Canonica (1762-1844). At its entrance on the city side, the Ruskins also viewed the arch commemorating Napeoleonʼs victory at Marengo (now known as the Arco della Pace), designed by Luigi Cagnola (1762-1833), begun in 1807 and still incomplete when the Ruskins visited. On their last day in Milan, they viewed Cagnolaʼs city gate built “in memory of [Napoleonʼs] victory at Marengo”, today known as the Porta Ticinese (1801-14) (Kirk 77-83, 91-98).

See Ruskin's planned section of the "Account" on the Corso of Milan and associated glosses. These Napoleonic projects were designed to impress an imperial stamp on the principal cities of the Italian kingdom. The Amphitheatre was built to stage military parades and spectacles; and the arch proclaimed a ceremonial finish for the Simplon road, which was extended into Milan under the name of the Strada Napoleone (Gregory, Napoleonʼs Italy, 75–76). At the time of the Ruskinsʼ visit, the latter monument not only remained under construction, like the Duomo, but was also in process of redefinition. As explained in Murrayʼs guide to northern Italy (1847), the triumphal arch was begun in 1806–7 as the “Arch of the Simplon . . . in commemoration of the battle of Jena”—Napoleonʼs victory over the Prussian army, in the war against the Fourth Coalition of allies—and the monument was meant to be decorated “with bas‐reliefs representing the events of Napoleonʼs wars”; however, when the Kingdom of Italy fell and Milan returned to control by Austria, the name of the monument “was changed to the Arch of Peace, . . . and the sculptures underwent a transformation to make them represent the events which preceded the general peace” (completed after the Ruskinsʼ visit, in 1838, for the Milan coronation of the Austrian emperor, Ferdinand I). (Maule, Hand‐book for Travellers in Northern Italy, 147).
